title: Wednesday, 11th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hi.

BE11:04am

Guess we have to start with a picture. Tradition etc.

BE11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:04am

What's that? Oh, that's Smith & Nephew 1yr.

BE11:05am

Top chart is the share price, which you'll see is at a record high.

BE11:05am

And below that is volume.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

That big spike on September 14? Yeah. That is a big spike, isn't it.

BE11:07am

That was slightly more than 4m shares going through the market at £13.83.

BE11:07am

(Then getting booked twice again during the auction, for reasons I'm sure a trader can explain.)

11:07 am
BE11:08am

That position's quite in the money now!

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,404, up 45 (+3.31%), High: 1,416, Low: 1,391, Volume: 4.09m
BE11:08am

In part thanks to Bloomberg hitting the button on a story overnight that Elliott Advisors has built a stake.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

One of those size-undefined stakes. BTW, that line up there in the volume spike represents about 0.5% of Smith & Nephew, I note apropos of nothing.

BE11:10am

Anyway, weirdest thing.

BE11:11am

Pretty much immediately after that big volume spike on September 14, we started hearing all sorts of rumours.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Takeover stuff mostly, though without any kind of names or specifics. Which always makes a rumour very difficult to confirm or deny.

BE11:12am

It's noise, but it's noise the market tends to respond to, as per the chart above.

BE11:14am

The noise was certainly quite useful for whoever got in at £13.83! But anyway, let's backtrack.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Elliott's in, intentions unknown. S&N's CEO stuck out the weird "I'm going to retire at the end of 2018" statement a day or two ago so management change seems to be parked for the moment.

BE11:16am

Given S&N's execution record, management change seems the easiest push for an activist. This per Morgan Stanley.

BE11:16am

Over the past 10 years we have seen SN being subject to a material valuation de-rating vs. its orthopaedic peer group from a 10-year average EV/EBITDA of 0.98x to 0.81x currently. We believe this is driven by inconsistent execution on organic sales growth as well as margin expansion. Furthermore, the allocation of capital for growth acquisitions such as Bioactives (acquisition of Healthpoint) have not worked out as well as expected in our view.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

..... or maybe breakup? This per Citigroup.

BE11:17am

The perennial question of splitting SN up: it has often been speculated that SN may be broken up into its core ortho business (FY16A revenue $3,436mn) and its wound business ($1,233mn) (e.g. Break-up talk pushes S&N higher, Financial Times, 28 March 2014). We think it is worth noting that SN has been consistent in its language that it sees itself as acquirer rather than target, and we would point out that given the highly challenged integration of Zimmer and Biomet, existing ortho players may not be predisposed to such a transaction, while Stryker has been consistently taking market share organically on its own.

BE11:17am

Here's that 2014 report they reference, BTW: https://www.ft.com...-8695-00144feabdc0

11:18 am
BE11:18am

....... Which was just fantasy M&A off the back of an Investec note, and having to read it again this morning was a bit second-reel-of-Groundhog Day.

BE11:19am

So, if not a breakup, what? Debt, tax dodging, sacking people .....

BE11:19am

Back to Citi:

11:19 am
BE11:19am

What about existing levers in the business? There are a few classic levers that could be pulled to reach a bull case on SN. For example:

BE11:19am

1] Leverage: SN is relatively conservative with leverage at c. 1x net debt / EBITDA, moving to 3x would add around $2.8bn of capital, which in theory could reduce the share count by c. 22% or drive acquisitions.
2] Tax: Acceleration of existing plans to cut the tax rate at SN may also be a factor, with every 2% reduction in the effective rate (currently c. 24%) worth around $20mn to earnings or +3%.
3] Growth & margins: driving organic sales growth back to c. +4% (from c. 3%) is worth around $48mn to sales or c. $24mn to EBITA (assume 50% conversion margin) or about +2% to earnings. Beyond this, adding c. 100bps to EBITA margins is worth around $37mn to earnings or c. +4.6%.

BE11:20am

As an arbitrary illustration, on our preliminary math doing all 3 of the above would drive 2019E cash EPS of c. $1.29, which on the current 21.5x multiple and discounted back at 8% a year (then converted to GBP) would be around £17.8 per share, or c. 30% upside from the October 10 close.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

..... though the question undermining all that is whether Elliott knows better than Olivier Bohuon about how to run a medical devices company.

BE11:22am

They might know more about how to extract value from one. Some might argue that the past few weeks have already proved that.

BE11:24am

.......... anyway, we have S&N results due Friday November 3rd. They'll be bad due to hurricanes, which have an effect because Florida is Glastonbury for hip replacement operations.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

And of course, with Elliott already in profit on an very small undisclosed stake and having (possibly) helped along a management change already, we have no visibility whatsoever on when they choose to take profit.

BE11:26am

But that's enough S&N.

undefined
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Kraftliner. Right.

Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 1,931, down 158 (-7.56%), High: 1,971, Low: 1,904, Volume: 3.26m
BE11:26am

Warning.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Prices go up at both ends of the market.

BE11:28am

As in, all the end market price hikes we've been talking about since January have been mirrored by an increased cost of pulp.

BE11:29am

Here's what's happening to forecasts, via Davy.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

While underlying demand and pricing remains strong across most of Mondi’s divisions, this has not been sufficient to offset cost and FX pressures. This is likely to result in a 2-3% reduction in our full-year forecasts. The issue facing the industry now is whether, given the strong demand fundamental, it has the capacity to recover cost increases. Over time, we expect that it will but margin pressure may persist in the short term.

BE11:30am

“Modestly below” market expectations is the guidance, which tends to mean 3-5% I thought.

BE11:31am

Jefferies is middle of that range.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

4% 2017 Downgrade: While confident of sustained 2017/18 organic volume growth and
successful price rises, due to industry-wide cost inflation (wood, energy, chemicals) and modest FX headwinds, we downgrade 2017 EBIT/EPS 4% to €1,010m EBIT/€1.47 EPS. Expect similar cost pressures at packaging peers Smurfit Kappa and DS Smith.

BE11:31am

Investments, M&A & Cash Return: Ramp-up of 2016 investments on track to deliver
incremental €25m 2017 EBIT. Post €38m Jan17 consumer packaging bolt-on, further M&A
under evaluation. With modest 0.9x 2017F Net Debt/EBITDA and confidence in 2018 profit growth/cash generation, without further M&A, Jefferies sees a probable 2018 special dividend.

BE11:31am

Key risk is macro impacting demand/prices. While any forecast reduction is disappointing,
with an improving European macro outlook we remain confident of 2017/18 Mondi profit
growth and cash generation from organic volume growth with pricing power. Mondi trades
on 2018F 8.6x EV/EBITDA & 15.2x PE (discount to peers) for sector-leading 18.7% ROCE with
flexibility for capital investments, M&A and likely 2018 special dividend. Reaffirm Buy with
£23 PT (based on 9.2x CY18 EV/EBITDA, in line with peer average).

11:32 am
BE11:32am

UBS as well? Why not. Can't have enough packaging forecasts.

BE11:32am

Underlying performance for the year is expected to be modesty below consensus
expectations reflecting currency moves and the impact of cost inflation. We reduce our
2017E underlying EBIT forecast by -2.7% to €1016m vs company collated consensus at
€1056m – about half of our EBIT downgrade reflects currency moves since H1. We also downgrade our 2018E EBITA by 4% reflecting the lower base, further currency impacts and cost inflation, while assuming limited Y/Y incremental price momentum.

BE11:32am

We would expect the shares to be slightly weaker on this announcement given a generally favourable backdrop on the pricing side being offset by the cost increases. However, we still see an attractive medium term fundamental outlook for volumes and pricing and an underlying 7-9% FCF can support cash returns, with a possible special return on the agenda for Q1 2018E. Our price target is increased to RCnt41350 from RCnt40650 to reflecting currency movements more than offsetting the impact of our slightly reduced forecasts – it is still set at 13x18E EV/EBIT.

11:32 am
Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,211, down 65.74 (-2.89%), High: 2,273, Low: 2,199, Volume: 864.47k
DS Smith PLC (SMDS:LSE): Last: 483.10, down 17.9 (-3.57%), High: 494.00, Low: 481.40, Volume: 2.14m
BE11:34am

Etc.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:34am

And so, we lollop into fantasy M&A.

BE11:34am

Or, mostly, reverse fantasy M&A.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Pfizer, of course, broke during yesterday's session.

BE11:36am

Reckitt had a run on the back of the news, on the idea that it can afford one more deal I guess.

BE11:36am

Hypothetical Pfizer CH deal could enhance RB's EPS by c.9% in year 3 and could be all debt funded, on our estimates.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

That was Merrill.

BE11:37am

At current valuation levels (absolute and relative P/E at three and five year lows respectively and 2018E FCF yield of 6%), we argue that the risks are skewed to the upside on an organic basis alone. The possibility of further M&A in health increases the upside, in our view, as M&A has proved to be one of RB’s core competencies. We expect management’s appetite for the deal to be high as Pfizer is seen as the last viable health target of size and one that fills two key whitespaces for RB: US analgesics and digestive remedies.

BE11:04am

Good morning. Welcome, whatever.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Mead Johnson complicates the issue for RB: Having closed on 15 June, the acquisition of Mead Johnson adds potential financial and operational hurdles for further M&A at RB. However, we argue that both are surmountable: 2018E net debt/EBITDA would reach 4.5-5.0x based on our valuation range (versus 2.0x in published forecasts) with high-single-digit/low-double-digit earnings accretion from a straight combination, ie assuming no synergies. The group’s net debt/EBITDA went to 4.0x after the acquisition of Mead Johnson, prior to the disposal of food, and further cash could be raised either by divestment (the home care category, which accounts for £2bn revenue, is not prioritised by management) or share issuance. The decision to operate Mead as a standalone business also reduces operational complexity.

BE11:39am

And then there's Exane.

BE11:39am

Jeff Stent. Who's pretty sure that Reckitt is a bit of a dog.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And that shareholders have somehow got it into their heads that Reckitt's a target, which it probably isn't because it's a bit of a dog.

BE11:41am

[W]e believe that it is not only one-off issues that have been impacting growth at Reckitt and core business sales are now trending at a relatively unexciting underlying rate (c.2%). Keeping this in mind, Reckitt holders appear to be increasingly focused upon the belief that it is a viable acquisition candidate and/or further M&A can drive upside in the shares.

BE11:41am

Firstly, we believe that any interested parties would approach Reckitt with much caution due to concerns around the robustness of its infrastructure (given its exceptionally high margin) and the self-proclaimed uniqueness of its culture. In addition, while Health may hold strategic interest, Reckitt’s Home, Hygiene and Portfolio assets would likely be of more limited interest to many.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Within we undertake a comprehensive acquirer appraisal and consider the likely interest levels of Abbott, Colgate, Bayer, Glaxo, Henkel, J&J, Kraft Heinz, Nestle, P&G, Sanofi and Unilever. We conclude that in reality the likelihood of a bid is slim. We view J&J as the most likely suitor (but even here we believe the chances are low).

BE11:42am

As to the recent gossip around Reckitt spinning off its airfresheners and focusing solely on OTC drugs ...........

BE11:42am

As to a split or disposal of Home, we struggle to envisage either being catalysts. Furthermore, wrt. Home, Henkel aside (usually a value-orientated acquirer), we struggle to envisage who would have interest in acquiring an asset that appears to now offer limited (if any) growth. As to Merck KGaA’s
/ Pfizer’s Consumer businesses, given competition, these will likely command very high multiples.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

In conclusion, we struggle to see M&A being a remedy to Reckitt’s current woes. With underlying sales growth seemingly at lacklustre levels, the temptation is to look for another ‘story’, we believe there isn’t one

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,068, down 22 (-0.31%), High: 7,131, Low: 7,052, Volume: 537.96k
undefined
11:44 am
BE11:45am

(@Soundbuy: the downside of being able to drink before midday is needing to drink before midday.)

BE11:45am

ROTR, I'll get onto satellites before we're done.

BE11:45am

We've a few other things to tackle first.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Meggitt, for instance.

Meggitt PLC (MGGT:LSE): Last: 518.50, down 1.5 (-0.29%), High: 521.50, Low: 515.00, Volume: 191.56k
BE11:47am

Which saw some interest yesterday on the back of Honeywell's spinoff thing.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

https://www.ft.com...-aab9-abaa44b1e130

BE11:47am

US industrial conglomerate Honeywell will spin off its turbo charger unit and home heating and security businesses to create two new publicly listed companies in response to pressure from activist investor Third Point.

The move, the result of a portfolio review undertaken by chief executive Darius Adamczyk, falls short of Third Point’s demand that the company spin off its entire aerospace division.

BE11:48am

...

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Mr Adamczyk said Honeywell would spend the proceeds to pay down debt, repurchase shares and look for merger and acquisition opportunities in all its remaining businesses, including aerospace. “We are going to be very active in the M&A arena,” he said on a call with company analysts.

BE11:48am

In an interview with the Financial Times, Mr Adamczyk countered the claim that Honeywell was too small to compete in this sector: “We don’t compete in our aerospace segment based on scale, we compete on technology differentiation.”

As to whether he planned more acquisitions to build the aerospace business, Mr Adamczyk said: “I don’t think we have to do M&A but we are certainly open to it.”

BE11:49am

So ...... Honeywell for Meggitt? Can we drag that old theory out of the file, dust it down and give it another outing?

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Sandy Morris of Jefferies says, don't bother.

BE11:49am

HON is an “Industrial Software” business. We are not clear Aircraft Brakes fit into that. Further, go to HON’s homepage, hover on “Industries”, click “Aerospace”, and then click “Products”. A list emerges, but there is no sign of Brakes. Meggitt’s share price was unchanged yesterday. That could be the correct reaction. Equally, if HON’s Brakes do not fit the Industrial Software model and have been de-emphasised, is not Meggitt a likely buyer? Is Meggitt the prey or predator? We’re not sure.

BE11:50am

(@Soundbuy: sold in January I think.)

11:50 am
BE11:50am

(Making it an excellent example of Elliott coming in, doing not much, and selling out again.)

undefined
BE11:52am

More! More fantasy M&A! We're in a moribund market! Turn all the sellside into pitchbooks!

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Here's Credit Suisse saying Whitbread should do something.

BE11:53am

Whilst there has been no specific indication of activist or PE interest, WTB has been the subject of regular takeover/spin-off press speculation (2005, 2006, 2007, 2015 and 2016) but the P/E relative valuation (to FTSE250) is at a ten-year low. Hence the potential upside from the five options we consider is very compelling. We maintain an OP rating with 26% potential upside to our new target price of 4880p (from 4870p).

BE11:54am

(That "2005, 2006, 2007, 2015 and 2016" links to three old Times market reports, all of which I suspect I wrote as well. We're forming into a kind of a self-perpetuating Möbius strip of fantasy M&A here.)

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Highlighting five options to realise value: With rising shareholder activism, record private equity dry powder and with WTB trading on an historically cheap valuation we consider five options: 1) Release property value (64% of EV) – our updated Feb-18E property value is £5.4bn which equates to 64% of EV and 77% of mkt cap). 2) Spin-off Costa (30% of EV) – 200bps of margin re-investment has occurred and prospective EBITDA growth matches Starbucks yet our SOTP applies a c30% EBITDA discount. Assuming a zero value in our SOTP yields 3760p indicating there is very little in the price for Costa. 3) Exit pubs (8% of EV) given the managed pub sector is sub cost of capital with an aggregate 2016 HOLT® CFROI® of 6.1%. Recycling capital into Premier Inn would create a further £540m of value (6% of EV). 4) Add leverage (28% of EV) with scope for £2.4bn more debt if geared to 5x lease adjusted leverage. 5) Tackle the cost base (11% EV) – 2017 staff numbers rose just 2% (vs 2010-16 avg 8%) – if sustained this could add +£900m of value by 2021E.

BE11:55am

Deep value support: 1) WTB has never been cheaper on P/E relative in the last ten years vs the FTSE250 (8% PE discount vs 10yr premium of 17%) and trades at parity to the structurally challenged UK retail sector (vs 10 yr premium of 28%). 2) Our DCF and SOTP based TP implies 26% potential upside. 3) HOLT shows the shares are discounting a t+5 CFROI of 6.3% vs 8.3% in Feb-17 and a recessionary 6.1% in Feb-10.

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,977, up 82 (+2.11%), High: 3,983, Low: 3,902, Volume: 234.81k
11:56 am
undefined
BE11:57am

Oh, cool, the ROTR's fighting about Brexit. There's not enough places on the internet to talk about Brexit. I'm glad you're using our pixels to have the same damn arguments again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again.

BE11:58am

Meanwhile, over on this side of the page, couple of things to round up with.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There's Provident Financial ..........

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 795.44, down 41.06 (-4.91%), High: 824.50, Low: 752.50, Volume: 1.86m
BE11:58am

..... which is on Barclays saying sell into the recent rebound.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The Q3 trading update is on 13 Oct 2017. We are cautious on the shares given our lack of
confidence for a turnaround of the Home Credit business and the unquantifiable size of
potential FCA redress. We perceive further tail risks of PFG not being able to meet its Oct-
19 debt obligation, breaching of debt covenants and the impact of IFRS9 accounting.
These assumptions are not baked into our base case but we believe could have a meaningful impact on earnings and cost of funding. Downgrade to UW, PT to 584p.

BE11:59am

Interesting bit:

BE12:00pm

We estimate Vanquis can afford a £200m ROP fine or refund, but the amount could be greater: We are concerned by comments we have found online of Vanquis customers who believe they have been mis-sold the ROP product. If fined by the FCA, we estimate Vanquis can only pay ~£200m from existing liquidity headroom and retained earnings if it is to be able to repay its Oct-17 and Oct-19 bonds whilst maintaining a CET1 ratio for Vanquis above 20%. We now forecast no dividend in 2018E. We see downside risk of a refund of more than £200m as it could include accrued interest as well as ROP fees.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

I'll screenshot the comments they pick out, for convenience.

BE12:01pm

BE12:02pm

Right-click-open-new-window for embiggening.

12:02 pm
undefined
BE12:03pm

(@ROTR: it stands for Rise of the Robots, because unless proven otherwise we assume you're Russian bots sent to undermine western capitalism.)

BE12:04pm

Over time. Nevertheless ..........

12:04 pm
Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,494, up 0.6 (+0.04%), High: 1,506, Low: 1,460, Volume: 566.38k
BE12:06pm

Not sure I recognise the short data cited above, but don't have time to check immediately.

BE12:06pm

Q1's fine anyway.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Here's Numis to explain the ways in which it's fine.

BE12:07pm

As expected HL have reported a good Q1 performance with revenue increasing 15% to £104.1m and AuA increasing 3.5% in the quarter to £82.0bn. Customer numbers increased by 30,000 to 983,000 50% ahead of the 20,000 added in Q1 last year and net inflow increased 39% to £1.54bn against the £1.11bn reported last year. We believe that HL will be the largest beneficiary of the fallout from the system migration problems at Barclays, which caused many problems for a large number of Barclays Stockbrokers' accounts. We would, however, caution that, as well as clients not being able to log into their accounts and not receiving their dividends, the exit process appears to be delayed as well. Consequently, we expect a lag between clients choosing to move to HL and the AuA arriving. If a client is transferring HL will only recognise them when their balance is over £100. Consequently, if the transfer is delayed, client and AuA recognition could be delayed as well and for this reason we expect HL to report strong net flows and customer growth in Q2 as well. A good performance was expected and consequently at this stage we are not changing our top of the range forecasts. We continue to believe HL offers investors an attractive medium to long term growth story and consequently we believe it more than justifies its 29x earnings multiple.

BE12:07pm

Structural growth: We believe that, even without the growth that we expect to come from the HL savings businesses, HL offers investors a structural growth opportunity. The shift from institutionally managed defined benefit pension schemes to retail managed defined contribution schemes is expected to see the average client portfolio triple in size. Additionally, the shift to individually managed portfolios away from advisor management has commenced. In the US it has fallen from 80% of assets to less than 50% in a decade and we believe the UK will follow a similar path. We see these two trends driving growth in AuA of c.15% per annum for at least the next decade. A combination of RDR repricing and the fall in interest earned on client cash has seen profitability lag AuA growth in recent years. With these impacts largely behind the group pricing we believe AuA growth will drive profit growth.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

That's James Hamilton, who's good. Not always right, directionally speaking, but good.

BE12:10pm

(@LegalEagle: np, ignore me. I'm just grumpy.)

BE12:11pm

And that, I think, will do. Can't find the Inmarsat thing immediately so we'll come back to that when I have something to add.

12:11 pm
BE12:12pm

Let's close this and get on with our lives.

BE12:12pm

Back tomorrow. Same schtick. Afternoon all.

BE11:38am

That's Berenberg, whose working goes like this ......
